content:
This must be an extremely basic question but it keeps confusing me.

I'm on Level 1 of Advanced Multiplication world.

theorem mul_le_mul_right (a b t : ℕ) (h : a ≤ b) : a * t ≤ b * t := by

Suppose I start with

induction b with d hd
rw [zero_mul]

At this point I got:

Assumptions:
h: a ≤ 0

Goal:
a * t ≤ 0

Now, my thinking is — "I'll show that a <= 0 means a = 0, and then use that information to reach the goal". But this is where I get stuck.

I do have le_zero in my arsenal:

le_zero (x : ℕ) (hx : x ≤ 0) : x = 0

So naturally what I want is to apply le_zero to my h to get a = 0 that I can later use. But how do I do that? The only relevant tactics we've learned in NNG so far seem to be:

  • apply: It goes backwards so not what I want. I.e. It would help me get from a = 0 in a goal to a <= 0 but I want to do the opposite to my hypothesis.
  • exact: This works as a "last step" (if a = 0 was my goal I could just write exact le_zero a h). But I'm not at the last step yet.

Is the problem just that we're not yet familiar (at this level of NNG) with creating intermediate variables and so I'm really being forced to "massage" my goals first? I.e. I really have to work backwards before trying to apply this?

Or am I missing some basic method that was taught earlier in NNG?

Thanks!
I don't know if it was explicitly introduced in the NNG, but you can use apply le_zero at h to replace h with a=0. It does look like the docstring mentions this syntax.
I guess have is introduced later on, but that's a more general way to create a new hypothesis.

Ah you're right, that was taught! So I guess what I didn't realize is that apply does a different thing depending on the context — it seems like it works "forwards" with at. Not sure how I missed that!
Dan Abramov has marked this topic as resolved.

Bryan Gin-ge Chen said:

I don't know if it was explicitly introduced in the NNG, but you can use apply le_zero at h to replace h with a=0. It does look like the docstring mentions this syntax.

apply at was introduced into mathlib as a direct result of me pushing to have it in NNG because mathematician users found apply too confusing! It was in NNG before it was in mathlib ;-)
